policies.title: Economic Freedom & Anti-Cronyism
policies.shortDescription: Remove government-created barriers that protect established interests and distort free markets; combat regulatory capture.
policies.overview: The fundamental problem is cronyism ‚Äî the merger of economic and political power where government picks winners and creates barriers that protect established players. This isn't free-market capitalism; it's regulatory capture.

subPolicies.title: Medicare Bid Reform
problem: Medicare Advantage insurers bid annually for contracts
Bids are proprietary and hidden from public view
No transparency in how taxpayer dollars are spent
Rural areas often have fewer plan options
Impossible for citizens to evaluate value for money
positions: Mandatory public disclosure of all Medicare Advantage bids
Standardized reporting format for easy comparison
Rural access requirements in bidding process
Public dashboards showing cost vs. outcomes by plan
Penalties for insurers who consistently underperform
subPolicies.framing: Taxpayers deserve to know how their Medicare dollars are spent. Transparency ensures accountability and better care.

subPolicies.title: Occupational Licensing Reform
problem: Over 25% of American workers now need government permission to work (up from 5% in 1950s)
Licensing boards dominated by industry incumbents
Creates barriers for military spouses, interstate movers
Disproportionately hurts low-income workers
Often serves to limit competition rather than protect consumers
positions: Sunrise/Sunset Reviews: New licenses require proof of actual public harm; existing licenses reviewed every 7 years
Interstate Reciprocity: Full recognition of out-of-state licenses
Least Restrictive Alternative: Require use of registration, certification, or bonding before full licensing
Board Composition Reform: No more than 1/3 of licensing board can be active practitioners
Criminal Justice Reform: Ban blanket prohibitions on licenses for people with criminal records
subPolicies.framing: Government should only require a license when there's clear evidence of public harm. Let people work.

subPolicies.title: Right to Repair
problem: Manufacturers restrict access to repair manuals, tools, and parts
Software locks prevent independent repair
Farmers can't fix their own tractors
Creates monopoly on repairs, drives up costs
Increases e-waste and reduces product lifespan
positions: Mandate availability of parts, tools, and documentation to independent repair shops and owners
Prohibit software locks that prevent repair
Ban manufacturer retaliation against repairers
Fair pricing requirements for repair parts
Environmental benefits: reduce e-waste, extend product life
subPolicies.framing: If you buy it, you own it. You should be able to fix it. Right to Repair is property rights.

subPolicies.title: Civil Asset Forfeiture Reform
problem: Police can seize property suspected of involvement in crime
No conviction required ‚Äî property itself is 'guilty'
Proceeds often go to police departments creating perverse incentive
Disproportionately affects low-income individuals who can't afford lawyers
Constitutional concerns: violates due process
positions: Require criminal conviction before asset forfeiture
Burden of proof on government, not property owner
End direct financial benefit to seizing agencies
Innocent owner defense must be robust
Full transparency: public reporting of all forfeitures
subPolicies.framing: This is government theft. Innocent until proven guilty applies to your property too.

policies.title: Food & Health Sovereignty
policies.shortDescription: Freedom to choose food and health products, prioritizing local production and producer-to-consumer channels.
policies.overview: People should have the freedom to choose their own food and health products, with full information and informed consent. Local production and direct producer-to-consumer relationships should be protected and expanded.

subPolicies.title: Raw Dairy Access & Labeling
problem: Federal regulations restrict raw milk sales across state lines
Many states ban raw dairy sales entirely
Limits consumer choice despite growing demand
Small dairy farmers shut out of market
Studies show low risk when handled properly
positions: Legalize raw dairy sales with mandatory labeling
Allow direct farm-to-consumer sales
Require clear health warnings on packaging
Regular testing requirements for safety
Interstate commerce protections
subPolicies.framing: Informed adults should be free to make their own food choices. Clear labeling ensures safety.

subPolicies.title: Local & Cottage Food Expansion
problem: Cottage food laws vary widely by state
Many states prohibit home-based food businesses
Excessive regulations prevent small-scale food entrepreneurship
Limits access to locally-produced foods
positions: Expand cottage food laws in all states
Raise sales caps for home-based food businesses
Reduce inspection requirements for low-risk foods
Allow online sales and shipping
Protect farmers market sales
subPolicies.framing: Support local food producers and entrepreneurship while maintaining basic safety standards.

subPolicies.title: Medical Freedom & Informed Consent
problem: Government and employers mandate medical procedures
Limited informed consent in many healthcare settings
Suppression of alternative viewpoints
Privacy concerns with medical data
positions: Robust informed consent requirements for all medical procedures
Protect right to refuse medical treatment
Medical privacy protections
Religious and philosophical exemptions
Ban discrimination based on medical choices
subPolicies.framing: Your body, your choice. Medical decisions should be between you and your doctor.

policies.title: Property Rights
policies.shortDescription: Defend ownership against government and private overreach; ensure fair treatment for property owners.
policies.overview: Property rights are fundamental to liberty. Owners should have control over their property, free from excessive government regulation and private entity overreach.

subPolicies.title: HOA Reform
problem: HOAs often abuse power with arbitrary rules
Foreclosure over minor violations
Lack of financial transparency
Self-dealing by board members
Difficult for homeowners to challenge decisions
positions: Term limits for HOA board members
Mandatory financial audits and transparency
Homeowner bill of rights
Restrictions on foreclosure powers
Easy appeals process for rule violations
Limits on fine amounts
subPolicies.framing: Your home is your castle. HOAs should serve homeowners, not rule them like tyrants.

subPolicies.title: Eminent Domain Reform
problem: Government takes private property for 'public use'
Post-Kelo, 'public use' includes private development
Compensation often below market value
No compensation for lost business or relocation costs
Abuse particularly affects low-income communities
positions: Constitutional amendment: Public use means true public use only
125% of fair market value compensation
Compensation for business losses and relocation
Right of first refusal if property not used as stated
Higher standards for proving public necessity
subPolicies.framing: Government shouldn't take your property to give to developers. When it must take property, compensation should be fair and generous.

subPolicies.title: Mineral Rights Protection
problem: Mineral rights often separated from surface rights
Foreign entities buying up mineral rights
Landowners unable to develop their own resources
Squatting on undeveloped mineral rights
positions: Protect active mineral rights holders
Fee structure for undeveloped rights held speculatively
Restrictions on foreign ownership of mineral rights
Surface owner protections during extraction
Right of first refusal for surface owners
subPolicies.framing: Mineral rights are property rights. Americans should control American resources.

policies.title: Government Accountability & Reform
policies.shortDescription: Reduce cronyism, increase transparency, and democratize influence in government.
policies.overview: Government must be accountable to the people. Reduce special interest influence, increase transparency, and ensure elected officials serve the public interest.

subPolicies.title: Congressional Stock Trading Ban
problem: Members of Congress consistently outperform market
Access to non-public information creates unfair advantage
Creates conflicts of interest in policymaking
Erodes public trust
positions: Ban individual stock trading by Congress and immediate family
Allow only broad index funds and blind trusts
Mandatory disclosure of all holdings
Criminal penalties for violations
Extend to senior executive branch officials
subPolicies.framing: If you make the laws, you shouldn't be able to profit from insider knowledge.

subPolicies.title: Term Limits
problem: Career politicians become entrenched
Seniority system rewards longevity over merit
Creates professional political class
Difficult to challenge incumbents
positions: 12-year limit for House and Senate combined
Prospective only (doesn't affect current members)
Constitutional amendment required
Alternatively: end seniority system advantages
subPolicies.framing: Citizen legislators, not career politicians. Fresh perspectives prevent corruption.

subPolicies.title: End Lobbying: Citizen Voice Portal
problem: Lobbyists have disproportionate access to lawmakers
Money buys influence through lobbying
Average citizens have no comparable voice
Revolving door between government and lobbying firms
positions: Replace paid lobbying with structured citizen input portal
AI-analyzed public comments on pending legislation
Lawmakers required to review and respond to constituent feedback
Ban former officials from lobbying for 10 years
Full transparency on all meetings and communications
subPolicies.framing: End the lobbyist gravy train. Every citizen should have equal voice in their government.

subPolicies.title: Regulatory State Reform
problem: Unelected bureaucrats write rules with force of law
Courts defer to agency interpretations (Chevron)
Regulations never expire even when outdated
Agencies act as investigator, prosecutor, and judge
positions: REINS Act: Major regulations require Congressional approval
End Chevron deference
10-year sunset on all regulations
Separate adjudication from enforcement
Cost-benefit analysis requirement
subPolicies.framing: Unelected bureaucrats shouldn't write laws. Regulations need democratic accountability.

subPolicies.title: Emergency Powers Reform
problem: Emergency powers invoked and never rescinded
Limited legislative oversight once declared
Executive branch accumulates power during emergencies
Abuse of emergency declarations
positions: 30-day automatic sunset on emergency declarations
Congressional approval required for extensions
Clear criteria for what constitutes emergency
Judicial review of emergency actions
Compensation for rights violations during emergencies
subPolicies.framing: Emergencies are temporary. Emergency powers must be too.

policies.title: Election Integrity
policies.shortDescription: Easy to vote, hard to cheat. Robust safeguards alongside broad participation.
policies.overview: Elections must be secure, transparent, and accessible. Every legal vote should count, and only legal votes should count.

subPolicies.title: Voter ID Requirements
problem: Inconsistent ID requirements across states
Concerns about voter impersonation
Lack of verification in some jurisdictions
positions: Mandatory photo ID for in-person voting
Free state-issued ID for all citizens
Mobile ID services for elderly and disabled
Multiple acceptable forms of ID
Provisional ballot option with ID cure period
subPolicies.framing: ID is required for everything else. Elections should be no different. We'll make sure everyone can get ID.

subPolicies.title: Paper Ballots & Audit Trails
problem: Electronic voting machines vulnerable to hacking
No paper trail in some jurisdictions
Difficulty conducting audits and recounts
Public distrust in electronic systems
positions: Mandatory paper ballots nationwide
Voter-verified paper trail for all electronic voting
Hand-marked ballots preferred
Machine-readable for quick counting
Risk-limiting audits after every election
subPolicies.framing: Paper ballots can't be hacked. They provide the gold standard for election security.

subPolicies.title: Chain of Custody Protocols
problem: Unclear custody of ballots in some jurisdictions
Opportunities for tampering or loss
Lack of transparency in ballot handling
positions: Strict chain of custody requirements
Bipartisan observation at every step
Video surveillance of ballot storage
Tamper-evident seals and containers
Real-time tracking systems
subPolicies.framing: Ballots should be treated like evidence in a trial: documented custody at all times.
